intro: Viola adunca var. bellidifolia, commonly known as the bellflower viola, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 15–30 centimeters, featuring heart-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces clusters of small, violet or purple flowers with a distinctive bell-shaped appearance. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks. Its flowers bloom in early spring, adding a delicate touch of color to the landscape.
